Some work has been proposed to use an arti.cial neu­ral network (ANN) as the controller of game agents [6] [7], proving that an ANN could control game characters in a non predictable way and generate correct behaviours in scenar­ios where other classic techniques are not easily applicable [3]. Unfortunately, in order to get a stable ANN controller, a process of several training steps and experiments is re­quired which is resource intensive because of the high di­mensionality of the weight space and the high number of local minima[8]. This results in the impossibility of contin­uing learning once the game is released due to the high risk of producing erratic behaviours. Support Vector Machines (SVMs) are statistical learn­ing methods which have some properties that make them suitable to be used as controllers for non-player characters (NPCs). Unlike arti.cial neural networks, SVMs will pro­duce one optimal solution that maximizes the distance be­tween classes. That property, in conjunction with the use of cross-validation [5] to .nd good values for the parameters of the algorithm,o.ers a method for continuous learning; i.e. learning during game execution. An SVM, unlike an ANN, produces an unique optimal solution for a given set of parameters and training set. This makes possible reliable evolution of NPC behaviour. If a new solution tested in a continuous learning phase performs poorly against a valida­tion set it can be dropped in favour of the existing solution. With an ANN there is no guarantee that a new solution is an improvementorisevenasgood. Current literature about using SVMs in games is limited. Hamaide [4] describes how to use SVMs as a model of short­termmemory which is not quite the approach proposed in this paper but still is a good example of the potential use of SVMs. 2. DESCRIPTION 2.1 Support Vector Machines An SVM is a linear classi.er and its goal is to .nd a hy­perplane that separates the classes and maximizes the dis­tance between the hyperplane and the closest patterns of each class. This distance is referred to as the margin. Figure 1 shows di.erences between the margins of two possible solutions. In cases of non-linearly separable clas­si.cation problems, it is necessary to map input data to ahigherdimension space where that data can be linearly 33 Figure 1: Decision hyperplanes Table 1: Training examples used to control a NPC Bullets left Stamina Enemies near Behaviour 0 100 0 Explore 10 50 1 Attack 8 20 1 Run Away 4 10 2 Run Away 10 80 2 Attack 4 80 3 Run Away 2 50 0 Explore classi.ed. The function that maps input data to a higher dimensional feature space is called the kernel A more detailed description of SVMs and how they can solve a non-linear classi.cation problem can be found in [1] and [2]. 2.2 Architecture For non-player character control, a multi-class classi.ca­tion problem is de.ned with a high dimensional vector as input where each dimension corresponds to a measure for a particular feature in the environment. The output is de­.ned as a label that corresponds to a behaviour that the NPC should perform. Table 1 illustrates how this could be applied to a shooter game. Even after the SVM is trained and tested during game development it is possible to use it for continuous learning since SVM learning is more e.cient than ANN learning. In the current research project it is hoped to demonstrate that it is possible to use it e.ectively during pauses in gameplay, such as when a level is being loaded. SVM methods have been proposed to solve classi.cation problems in a systematic fashion. For instance, Hsu et al[5] proposed a simple procedure aimed at beginners which gives reasonable results . It is possible to adapt this method to address the continuous learning problem. The method proposed to achieve continuous learning can be summarized in the following steps: Collect data when the game is running In any loading stage, .nd a set of values with low train­ ing error rate for the parameters of the algoritm using cross-validation. Train using the parameters found in the previous step with the original training set plus the new data col­lected during the game. Test using a validation set. If the testing error is less than or equal to a constant tolerance then use the new SVM. If the error is greater than the tolerance then forget the new data and use the last SVM. 3. CONCLUSION The pilot project currently under development uses an SVM to control an NPC in a third person shooter game. Continuous learning is explored in the .nal stage of the project. To validate results, agents using this technique will be contrasted with agents using FSMs and ANNs. Game applications for SVMs go beyond control of NPCs. For instance, they can be used for di.culty adjustment where NPCs can evolve and become harder to beat at the time that the human player is learning to master the game. An SVM could be used as an adjustment mechanism for helper AI agents which can learn favourite and/or undesir­able actions from the human player s decisions, permitting units to take independent actions according to the human player strategy. Also, over the shoulder helper AI agents could be able to detect inconvenient situations and launch a proper alert. 4. REFERENCES [1] C. J. C. Burges.
